title: Budget 2015: OBR says strong chance Osborne will not balance books by 2020
text:
Print 
Robert Chote, head of the Government's independent fiscal watchdog, says Chancellor's ability to deliver budget surpluses past 2020 will be hampered by Britain's demographic challenge 
The Government only has a 55pc chance of balancing the books by the end of the decade, according to its independent fiscal watchdog, which stressed that Britain’s ageing population would make the goal harder in future years. 
While Robert Chote, the chairman of the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), said that it was more likely than not that George Osborne would post a budget surplus by 2020, as well as keep net debt falling every year as percentage of gross domestic product (GDP), he said past performance suggested the probabilities were finely balanced. 
"The proposed fiscal mandate requires the Government to run a budget surplus in 2019-20 and to stay in surplus thereafter unless or until there is a ‘significant negative shock’ to the economy," said Mr Chote. 
"Our forecast shows the Government on course to meet this initial target with 0.4pc of GDP to spare, implying a 55pc chance of meeting it on past forecasting performance." 
Mr Osborne prepares to deliver his first "true Blue" Budget on Wednesday 
The Chancellor has moved to enshrine in law a commitment to post budget surpluses in times of growth, which he said on Wednesday would boost Britain's resilience to future economic shocks. 
Mr Osborne's new Fiscal Charter, which will be put to a vote this autumn, will apply at all times when there isn’t a recession or a marked slowdown. Mr Osborne said: "Only when the OBR judge that we have real GDP growth of less than 1pc a year, as measured on a rolling four-quarter basis, will that surplus no longer be required." 
Mr Chote said there had been six separate occasions since 1957 in which this has been the case. “Four of them involved a full blown recession with GDP falling for at least two quarters. The main exception was the recent slowdown in 2012, which breached the threshold without a full recession,” he said. 
Mr Osborne said if the Government broke these rules, it would be required to set out a plan to get the budget back into balance. 
"The Chancellor of the day will have to set out their plan with clear targets to restore the nation’s finances to health and this House of Commons will test the credibility of that plan and vote on those targets. It is sensible, pragmatic and it keeps Britain secure," he said. 
The OBR chairman has previously branded the Chancellor's goal of a budget surplus as "ambitious" and inconsistent with past trends. 
Mr Chote said that the government had about a 70pc chance of meeting its current fiscal mandate, which requires the Government to post a cyclically adjusted budget surplus - which accounts for booms and busts in the economy - in 2018-19, and get net debt falling as a share of GDP in 2016-17. 
Mr Chote said Britain’s demographic challenge would make future budget surpluses more challenging. 
"The Government’s ability to deliver budget surpluses further into the future will depend in part on how it deals with the challenges of an ageing population, which will put upward pressure on spending on health, long-term care and the state pension,” he said. “In our Fiscal sustainability report in June we projected that on unchanged policy this would see the budget surplus at the end of our March forecast return to a deficit by the mid-2020s.”
